Feature request: Turn ON night light from top bar

note.body:
Hmm i definitely disagree with the idea of removing the "turn off" option. 

The reason I suggest a more accessible on/off switch is that there are use cases where you might want to turn it off, then on again. 

I'm unable to list all those cases but consider the case when you watch a movie in e.g. VLC. The user wants to turn it off but once the movie's over he has to go to the settings to turn it back on.

You might argue that you could do this automatically but then again you'd have to differentiate between different full screen apps. The user might want to keep the night light when playing a game. 


I'm just spitballing here, but maybe there should be a keyboard short cut too? 


What do you think ?

events.target_title: Itunes Discover and Integration

note.body:
> Why should Apple get to curate all the world’s podcasts and decide which gets extra visibility?

To add to this, iTunes being the historical place where podcasts became mainstream, every podcast in existence (or almost all of them) will have an entry in the iTunes podcasts index. Apple even allows third-party applications to tap into this index, providing a search endpoint that does not go through the curating that Apple might do (I'm not a user, therefore I can't say).

Virtually every podcasting application in existence uses the iTunes index, that it has become expected of a new app to provide a way to search through it for podcasts.

As to the importance of this feature; while I have been able to find RSS links for all the podcasts I follow, instead of clicking 5 buttons inside the applications, I had to search different websites for an RSS link, which to somebody used to having a searchbar somewhere and/or not knowing the internal workings of podcast feeds might be confused. From a UX standpoint, an iTunes index search feature is a must-have.

events.target_title: App menu retirement

note.body:
I feel like having the primary menu hidden in an in-window navigation app would be a regression from current, as a primary menu may apply anywhere, and having the user modify (and especially here, undo) application state in order to access a particular menu item (that, again, by its definition can apply anywhere in the app) would lead to end-user frustration.

The "apps with sidebar" example is IMHO best as both menus are displayed and have a position that makes sense, and most importantly, both are visible at all times.

3.28 with app menu displayed in the application top bar best describes what to be would be a good behavior for primary menus.

events.target_title: New unlock/login design

note.body:
Allan,

In your design phase it seems that you have stopped just short of the point of giving users an option to disable the 'screen shield' part entirely. (which is now a clock or whatever). So that it never appears.

Now: I have read many, many other user reports of wanting to get rid of this in GDM3. So when i say: Denying the users this ability... is not acceptable in any way. I am not saying that because I think I am any kind of an authority on what users want. I am saying that because it is abundantly clear than many other people share the same view. And ignoring them / assuming that it is less of an issue than it really is.... is, well... Pretty ignorant of the general public who are using your software.

* Make the screen shield the default option - yes, fine.

* Improve the behaviour of the screen shield to make it considerably less annoying - great.

* Make all users endure this unnecessary visual distraction. Which serves no functional purpose other than to annoy users / hide the login screen... no. That is a step too far.

If you really care about finding out what users want, in the case when there is a binary yes/no decision to be made (that cannot be both). Then a public poll or something like that would make more sense than simply assuming / deciding.


For example:

https://www.easypolls.net/

Login screen, for Ubuntu / GNOME 3 / GDM 3:

Should users be given the ability to disable the 'screen shield' or 'clock / notifications screen' that drops down over the user login / password prompt?


However regardless of that I and many others would also argue that requiring such a binary decision is unnecessary in the first place. Because a setting to enable / disable this feature would satisfy everybody. And provide that desperately required element of user choice. Rather than require alienating a large percentage of the user base (either way around).

Furthermore, when I look in the dconf settings of Gnome 3, thee are many, many other less significant configuration options available. So why not this one? As far as I am aware, nobody has put forward any kind of a convincing case specifically for denying this option. Other than the usual rubbish of 'programs should not have settings', and 'users should not be permitted to configure anything', and 'everyone must have the exact same experience as everybody else otherwise something is terribly wrong with our design somewhere'. Which is utter nonsense. Life should include an element of diversity, and choice, and doing things differently. And this is no different. Where a balance must be struck is against 'too many choices'. And unnecessary levels of over-complexity. Rather than denying a fewer number of useful and meaningful choices entirely - this isn't it.

* Yes - we can see the whole notifications thing has a purpose.
* Yes - you hope to make the experience kinda similar to a phone.

But here's the thing:

A computer is not a phone. It's still not such a personal device. The screen is much smaller (on a phone). And we carry it everywhere with us, and one of it's main functions to us is actually to provide notifications. And we don't all carry our desktop computers with us everywhere. Only some of us. And some of those mobile computers have lids. And some do not. And so on, and so on... This is why this UI design needs some kinds of flexibility / leeway / configurability. To reflect the different ways that users actually use their devices.

events.target_title: New unlock/login design

note.body:
> There's no such screen in the new design.

Yes there is. (1/3) here.

Upon closer reading, you seem to be trying to justify it's existence as a way of notifications.

The reality is ---> a lot of that stuff (the notifications included) is not on the 'super essential' category --> too complicated ---> cannot realistically be implemented cleanly, without incurring a significant number of new edge cases

> I personally think we ought to build and test the thing before we have that conversation.

> If you want to have a conversation with me about design, please don't accuse me or the project of "rubbish" and "utter nonsense".

Sorry if I have offended you. Indeed my comments were a bit too harsh. But I am afraid it's not going to escape from [solve those issues being pointed to]. Because they seem to be the same kinds of views as multiple other people were already expressing here.

What I believe is more important is that:

You seem to be trying to find other reasons not to be having this difficult conversation in the first place. Rather than trying to actually address these issues with your design. Which needs to be changed. Well otherwise, why the heck would we all be complaining about it?

> If you want to get a more accurate view of how we approach configuration options, I'd recommend that you read [Havoc Pennington's post on the subject](https://ometer.com/preferences.html).

OK, read it. Someone else thinks their beliefs are more important than actual results. Big surprise --> Not impressed. It did not achieve anything because:

As the very large software development wheel turns, it repeats itself. What is that saying again? About repeating the same thing over and over again, but expecting there to be different results the next time around?

>> Yes - you hope to make the experience kinda similar to a phone.
> No, not really.

You did not approve of my comparison. Yet it's actually somewhat relevant, if we consider [phone|tablet] --> [as mobile devices]. Because it reveals:

The actual use cases behind these things. As in the real world mechanics of actually checking and looking at notifications. On a screen. And on a device.

If you have:

A personal notification device (like a tablet or a phone). Then you have a pressing need to see notifications on it. And it's relatively quick and easy to check notifications on them. No matter whatever tasks you happen to be doing. Whereas: Computers [laptops, and the larger side of tablet devices]. Those are different. because due to their lower level of portability, it is much more difficult to take them around with you. ---> less convenient devices for checking notifications [while the screen is actually locked].

And that is not an opinion. That is a statement made frequently by other people, who heavily use a wide range, and variety of those different devices. And already have notifications on all of them. The bigger devices inherently less practical / convenient for checking notifications on. This is a fact. This is not some type of a personal favour, what I am asking for you to understand. It is simply the way that things are.

Instead of that, we have:

A different use case, where people lock their screens, to actually physically get away from their devices. To get up, leave, and do something elsewhere. This is then indeed a desirable outcome. Because the user is no longer checking their notifications. Or doing anything else on their computer.

As a side-effect. This replacement use case also has the knock-on effect of further lowering the usefulness of computer lock screen notifications [on these larger, less portable devices]. Yet that is the very thing which you are trying to accommodate here, by having the 1/3 screen [in your mockups].

And I really don't have to explain this. Because these devices are pretty ubiquitous. And this same wheel has been re-invented many times already.

[and since you do not intend to provide any type user configuration option whatsoever. Which I recommended against, but you didn't want to discuss again, because your group policy, but lets nevermind that, we are discussing something else now].

Because there is no config option --->  Then removal of both notifications, and the [1/3] screen is entirely the direction which you should be heading towards instead. And that is not a gross step of over simplifying. But rather, it is a well considered, and discrete step of necessary simplification.

And if you were to actually smarten up even more, you would take the [wiser] pages out of the MacOS book, and just fade in/out the password entry field alone, whilst remaining in the [2/3] screen for the duration. Which I am only mentioning because (while that is already rather obvious) it is not something that happens to be indicated in those 3 mock up images. But it is relevant here because it helps the [2/3] screen to take on and absorb the remaining functional roles  of the previous [1/3] screen.

You also mentioned in your wiki page / design outline. That you want to provide a visual indicator. For unlocking with other security devices instead like [card reader], [fingerprint reader], or [hello webcam], or [whatever other authentication device]. So having the password entry field only appear for text entry makes sense in that wider context. It would not make sense to show it, if other authentication methods are available, then a password may not be required in the first place. Or if the device really is a tablet. Then present a keypad instead. And so on. It's all under the remit of the [2/3] screen in your mockups. This is something already solved in MacOS X. It already works there extremely well. And very few people complain about it. Don't re-invent the wheel for the sake of re-inventing the wheel. It can only end up with making something which is no longer circular.... Just make another wheel.

The key difference from the 'screen shield', or your [1/3] slide here, is that: when the user's username is already presented on the screen, it is immediately intuitive to them to begin typing their password. If they already know it. Wheras if the user is presented with a clock instead. Then it isn't immediately intuitive. This was also something previously commented about. And that is indeed, a compromised design.

Now after writing all that, I skimmed a few some of the previous comments here. And my comments: well they all appear to mostly what all of the other guys have been saying to you all along Alan. About where these amendments / changes should be made. And what they should be. Co-incidence huh? Or perhaps you will claim that I already read those comments, and copied from them? Yet nothing could be further from the truth. Because then I would have been able to save myself all that bother of writing this down in my own words and instead just would have saved a great deal of time saying: well I agree with [you other guys 1,2,3...] over here.

events.target_title: vte.sh: improvement - simple hook function to preserve user custom prompts
vte.sh: improvement - simple hook function to preserve user custom prompts

note.body:
Intersting. So then: wouldn't `eval $_vte_prompt_command_user` solve that issue?

BTW in the meantime i found something else which required some attention. Fix is here:

https://gitlab.gnome.org/dreamcat4/vte/commit/59d835f105dc1c464f4168e999b3af53c4a10dcb

Which was regarding not getting caught in a loop, if an external (custom prompt) were also to try fixing this issue too. If they were calling into the vte function themselves, directly / beforehand.

Below is the user example code, which shows how to avoid that. It's for the case when the other prompt program is loaded after vte.sh (not before), and would otherwise override and delete (not remember) the vte prompt:

```sh
~/.basrc or ~/.profile:

# vte.sh has already been sourced earlier in the file

# at end of ~/.basrc or ~/.profile:

# source liquidprompt
. ~/.dev/liquidprompt/liquidprompt


# insert these lines to your .bashrc or .profile, directly AFTER sourcing liquidprompt
if [ "${VTE_VERSION:-0}" -ge 3405 ] && [ ! "$_liquidprompt_vte_enabled" ] && [ "$PROMPT_COMMAND" = "_lp_set_prompt" ]; then

  # but sourcing this vte.sh file, it overwrites our prompt
  . /etc/profile.d/vte.sh

  _lp_set_prompt_vte()
  {
    _lp_set_prompt
    VTE_PWD_THING="\[$(__vte_osc7)\]"
    PS1="$PS1$VTE_PWD_THING"
  }

  # set it back, but appen vte afterwards
  PROMPT_COMMAND="_lp_set_prompt_vte"

  # tell vte.sh that the prompt has already been set, to include vte
  export _vte_prompt_enabled=true
  export _liquidprompt_vte_enabled=true
fi
```

This way, evince would cater to both preferences without obstructing the other.

Use `ld -b binary` to speed up GResource generation for linking
Use `ld -b binary` to speed up GResource generation for linking

note.body:
A new option and integration in meson would be awesome.

A binary file with ca 96M needs 0.23s with `ld -b binary`.
Encoding to hexadecimal in c file with xxd blows it up to 589M (and needs 26 seconds), compiling it to an object file with gcc needs 527s.

All measurements done on my Laptop with not very potent CPU.

events.target_title: Use `ld -b binary` to speed up GResource generation for linking

note.body:
I did some quick evaluation of the string idea.
Encoding as string with octal value escape codes does already bring significant improvement. My test file from before blows up from 96M to 384M (instead of 589M with xxd) and needs only 17s to compile instead of 527s. A more minimal variant produces a c file with only 270M but with 27s needs a bit more time to compile interestingly.

I attached the small converting c program i hacked together:
[convert.c](/uploads/241ce4be0d2bc7d775306122cbc06dbd/convert.c)

events.target_title: No music controls show on lock screen
Another way of doing CSD that could help Electron apps
Another way of doing CSD that could help Electron apps

note.body:
I apologize for incorrectly putting this in to GNOME issues, I wasn't sure if I should put it here or in GTK, I decided on here as all of the CSD initiative web pages were very focused on GNOME.

> This is a misunderstanding. The "C" in CSD stands for _client_, which means that decorations are _entirely_ under control of the client. GTK's headerbars are _one_ option to implement decorations, but apps are free to pick whatever they like (be it Qt, Motif, OpenGL, HTML+CSS or any other framework that allows them to draw a rectangle with buttons).

Thank you for clearing that up. But as far as I am aware it's the only option to have correct theme buttons on the window (easily).

> But anything GTK offers to app developers for its CSD support by definition will only benefit GTK applications, not any other toolkits which are what you appear to be concerned about.

I believe it would be a nice thing for GTK applications as well because it would remove the dividing line between title bar content and window content and give more flexibility. I would use it myself.

But my idea is mostly in response to this blog post: https://blogs.gnome.org/tbernard/category/initiative/

Which suggests that electron should expose the GtkHeaderBar to electron apps:
>This means it should be possible to make this happen on GNU/Linux as well without major changes to the app. However, some underlying work in Electron to expose the necessary settings to apps might be required first.

I think this solution would be easier for electron to implement than giving access to the GtkHeaderBar, as macOS version of electron already does it: https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/13616 ("hide title-bar but keep the traffic lights")

It would also save electron apps having to worry about design language in the header bar:
> Apps with custom design languages will have to be evaluated on a case-by-case basis. For example, Telegram’s design should be easy to adapt to a header bar layout. Removing the title bar and adding window buttons in the toolbar would come very close to a native GNOME header bar functionally.

This is glib loading the shared object `libdbus-glib-1.so.2` during initialization. The loading may have been invoked by libenchant. The syscall should be `mmap(NULL, 0x229D40, PROT_READ | PROT_EXEC, MAP_DENYWRITE | MAP_PRIVATE, 16, 0) = 0x00007F9F87BD3000`. This corresponds perfectly to the segment that was unmaped later.

I noticed this stack is extremely similar to the stack where `source->source_funcs` was initialized

#82 0x00005649fe28fd0a in main (argc=0x1, argv=0x7fffebb43438) at /usr/src/debug/app-editors/gedit-3.28.1/gedit-3.28.1/gedit/gedit.c:146
```

This should be.

```
(rr) enable 3
(rr) enable 4
(rr) c
[rr crashed at this point]
```

The watchpoints can be hit if enabled before this point (invokations of prepare have a similar backtrace as the SEGFAULT backtrace), so it is unlikely these watchpoints will be hit even if rr functions normally.

I'm currently unable to figure out how the two methods of closing is different, but I'll leave the majority of my debugging process here. I'll continue if I have any ideas.

This bug is the last annoyance I have about my switch to Gentoo (everything else I fixed / workarounded myself), so probably will look back on this from time to time, if it's not fixed.

Apologies if this comment is too long. I thought I'd paste as much debugging information as possible since I do not yet know the root cause. Separating the inline 'blocks' kinda destroys the flow.

events.target_title: Segfault in libglib-2.0 when exiting gedit

And in the normal exit one we have:
```

#76 0x00007fdad1ef3acf in call_in_idle_cb (user_data=0x5649ff310a40) at /usr/src/debug/dev-libs/glib-2.54.3-r6/glib-2.54.3/gio/gdbusconnection.c:4851
#77 0x00007fdacf032d4d in g_main_dispatch (context=0x5649fee75350) at /usr/src/debug/dev-libs/glib-2.54.3-r6/glib-2.54.3/glib/gmain.c:3142
```
So I looked into the source code of the callers of `_gedit_cmd_file_quit`:

This SEGFAULTs (and registered as the window close handler):
```c
static gboolean
window_delete_event (GeditWindow *window,
                     GdkEvent    *event,
                     GeditApp    *app)
{
	GeditWindowState ws;

	ws = gedit_window_get_state (window);

	if (ws &
	    (GEDIT_WINDOW_STATE_SAVING | GEDIT_WINDOW_STATE_PRINTING))
	{
		return TRUE;
	}

	_gedit_cmd_file_quit (NULL, NULL, window);

	/* Do not destroy the window */
	return TRUE;
}
```

This exits normally (and registered as the menu item handler):
```c
static void
quit_activated (GSimpleAction *action,
                GVariant      *parameter,
                gpointer       user_data)
{
	_gedit_cmd_file_quit (NULL, NULL, NULL);
}
```

The only difference? `window` is changed to `NULL`.

Indeed, if I only perform this change the SEGFAULT is gone:
```diff
diff -u /usr/src/debug/app-editors/gedit-3.28.1/gedit-3.28.1/gedit/gedit-app.c /var/tmp/portage/app-editors/gedit-3.28.1/work/gedit-3.28.1/gedit/gedit-app.c
--- /usr/src/debug/app-editors/gedit-3.28.1/gedit-3.28.1/gedit/gedit-app.c	2018-01-29 06:16:45.000000000 +0800
+++ /var/tmp/portage/app-editors/gedit-3.28.1/work/gedit-3.28.1/gedit/gedit-app.c	2018-08-15 20:39:16.326563678 +0800
@@ -1271,7 +1271,7 @@
 		return TRUE;
 	}
 
-	_gedit_cmd_file_quit (NULL, NULL, window);
+	_gedit_cmd_file_quit (NULL, NULL, NULL);
 
 	/* Do not destroy the window */
 	return TRUE;
```

It is obviously not a fix (if you close one window all windows are closed, but I'll look into why, when window is passed, SEGFAULTs.

note.body:
Made a quick mock-up. Concept is just to provide some indication in the font-list view that there are auxiliary documents available, let the user see what they are, and rely on the default MIMEtype handler to launch whatever viewer is appropriate if something is chosen.

![gtk-font-explorer-docs-mockup](/uploads/0024d5a4cbd9d764806cdd382ac869fc/gtk-font-explorer-docs-mockup.png)

events.target_title: Allow fonts to be removed/uninstalled

note.body: What is the definition of "removed" you have in mind? Because deleting the font binaries themselves is likely not always what the user wants to happen.

events.target_title: Allow fonts to be removed/uninstalled

note.body:
>  I'm not entirely sure what Fonts does when it installs a binary, but the opposite of that. I was imagining that it would be similar to deleting the binaries from `~/.fonts`.

Most of these copy the binaries into ~/.fonts (although I think `~/.local/share/fonts` is what it's supposed to be these days according to FHS/XDG/TLA regulation) when installing. Then updates fc-cache. Haven't looked here, though.

>  Oh, how come?

Typical scenario is that the manager handles "activation" and "deactivation", rather than deleting anything from the drive. So deactivation means moving the binaries out and to some predefined location (eg, `~/.local/share/fonts_inactive` although that is not a well-known, real-world location), updating the Fc cache again, but retaining them in the internal database so they can be reactivated later.

Common usage case: you have a project for a client where the client owns some (non-FOSS) fonts you're supposed to use; you activate the fonts when working on the project, then deactivate them otherwise because you don't have the license to use them elsewhere and want to avoid accidents.

Or you download and activate a bunch of fonts to test out, but don't want them all making your font menu a million miles long, so you deactivate the ones you're done with.

events.target_title: A better preview of each font in the content overview

note.body:
>  indicate which/how many weights are available for the font

This would need to be slightly more generic (ie, 'styles' rather than just 'weights', so if it's widths/italics/optical-size-variants, etc that would be counted), but the point is taken.

I obviously have extensive thoughts about which metadata would be worth presenting, but I can quickly add that 'glyph count' should certainly be there -- even in the simplest, non-"advanced view" is it a general shortcut to knowing how "pro" a font is.

events.target_title: Strange Directory Bug - Internet Explorer Temp Directory Used

note.body:
Hi Andre, 

No problem - Version 2.10.4

events.target_title: Strange Directory Bug - Internet Explorer Temp Directory Used

note.body:
@schumaml Not sure I'm clear on what you're asking, but in my case:

1. Used the Windows GIMP installer and chose the standard installation. Just selected D: drive instead of C: drive.

2. Have checked and there are no user or system environment variables relevant to GIMP that I can see.

3. It looks to me as though GIMP is choosing the temp directory by default i.e. all I'm doing is selecting the image file in GIMP using the normal "open" dialogue. GIMP is doing the rest.

I can say the "AppData\Local\Microsoft\Windows\INetCache\gegl-0.4\swap" temp directory (referred to in my initial post) is a hidden system directory is not accessible by the user, and that GIMP is creating the "gegl-0.4" and "swap" sub-directories. It will re-create them even if they are manually deleted using the command prompt as administrator :-)

events.target_title: Strange Directory Bug - Internet Explorer Temp Directory Used

note.body:
OK, here's the results:

1. Uninstalled GIMP.
2. Did a clean up (disk files and registry).
3. Fresh "standard" install of GIMP 2.10.4 to D:\Gimp 2.
4. In preferences set the "temp" and "swap" folders options to like folders on the D: drive.
5. Opened a large image file stored on D: drive.

Result, as per my initial post, the temp files were being stored on the C: drive. The D: drive was ignored (100% certain on this).

@ok Noted your comments with interest. Particularly your comment that "on Windows it follows XDG Base Directory Specification if XDG_CACHE_HOME is defined. If XDG_CACHE_HOME is undefined, the directory that serves as a common repository for temporary Internet files is used instead" You will see from my initial post that this is exactly the behaviour I have described. You will also see what I tried to solve it.

As you can see, I have set the temp/swap file directories on the D: drive using the GIMP options AND also tried this by altering the Config files direct. Also put the Widows swap file on the D: drive. Nothing has worked. If you have any suggestions about how I can manually define "XDG_CACHE_HOME" to use the temp/swap directories I have created I'm all ears. :-)

events.target_title: Strange Directory Bug - Internet Explorer Temp Directory Used

note.body:
@aklapper @ok 

OK think I found a solution (with the caveat that nothing else appears to have broken - yet)

I created the following user environment variable in Win 10: "XDG_CACHE_HOME" = "D:\GIMP 2". When I opened the large image on the D: drive in GIMP the program created the sub-directories "gegl-0.4\swap" in the GIMP 2 directory (which is on the D: drive in my case). Low and behold opening the "swap" subdirectory shows a temp file being build as the image is being loaded by GIMP!


So that's one way to define XDG_CACHE_HOME. :-)

events.target_title: Strange Directory Bug - Internet Explorer Temp Directory Used

note.body:
GIMP successfully opened the image, great testimony for the program really as no other image program I tried was able to handle the image. Here's some stats for those interested:

- Image is a greyscale 16bit geo .tif of the surface of Mars (satellite photo).
- Image size: 72247px x 245623px
- File size: 33GB
- Temp file size to open: 133GB
- File size reported by GIMP in the status bar: 97GB
- Took around 4 - 6 hours to open on my rig (went to bed B4 it finished) :-)

I'll leave this thread open for a few days in case anyone wants to comment on the cache (temp directory) issue further, then close it. @ok thanks for your comments re XDG_CACHE_HOME. Seems to have done the trick.

note.body:
I just tried out 2.10.4, and the color picker seems to remember the location it was last closed, and the first time it was opened was roughly where the color picker UI element was, so in 2.10.4 it's not an issue.  As far as other dialogs in 2.10.2 I am not sure, the dialogs seem to appear where the mouse cursor is so they of course spawn within real screen space.

Given that's the behavior of this version now, I suppose this bug is no longer an issue.

events.target_title: have "a" or "e" as archive keyboard shortcut
Include "Ctl - Alt - A" in keyboard shortcut guide.
Include "Ctl - Alt - A" in keyboard shortcut guide.

note.body:
Here was my user experience and let me know what you think if this warrants it: 

When I search "Evolution email keyboard shortcuts" on google, an old guide from 2013 is the first search result (no archive shortcut listed).

When I go to evolution "getting started/mail management" section and search for "archive" nothing shows up...it isn't featured in any of the keyboard shortcut sections either(see https://help.gnome.org/users/evolution/stable/). 

THOUGHTS: 
If it could be featured there that would be good. But I have a hunch that if you were to squeeze it in the shortcut guide, users would appreciate it...or link to the user guide (for more keyboard shortcuts visit:help.gnome.org/users/evolution***) and feature it there. 

Hope that makes my case. 

Thanks for your time and consideration either way.

events.target_title: Update emoji data to version 11
Update emoji data to version 11
Gimp Crash when idling
Font colour issues
Cannot set the print size of an image

note.body:
I can confirm that "File -> Page-setup" preferences do not stick, even on 2.10.4 (on Windows 10).  Everytime you open the dialog, A4 paper and Portrait orientation will be selected.

My guess (although I haven't looked at the source code... or any source code in over 25 years!) is that since the page setup properties do not stick, the actual printing portion is probably ok, but using default values.

events.target_title: Debugging with gdb and dependency on addtitional files
Debugging with gdb and dependency on addtitional files

note.body:
Thank you for clarifying the debug pipline!
I think I can resolve the problem now.

When run in debug mode, the program (subprocess with prepended gdb) is executed in my home directory and not in the install prefix path as I expected!

Is this because my buildconfig is messed up, or is this intended behavior?
I would expect the program to run in the install prefix.

events.target_title: Debugging with gdb and dependency on addtitional files

note.body:
That makes perfectly sense.
Will try to give it a look, but highly doubt that I can provide something useful.

Thank you for your great work!

events.target_title: Synctex was completely removed from gedit
Synctex was completely removed from gedit

note.body:
With 9f59fd82 reverted, the package compiles without any warnings or errors whatsoever concerning the synctex plugin. Also, the resulting synctex plugin works just fine.

Why was this plugin removed from the project?
Please revert this commit!

events.target_title: Synctex was completely removed from gedit

note.body:
There is some pretty good documentation in the evince manual:
https://help.gnome.org/users/evince/stable/index.html.en#synctex
The gedit documentation (for the synctex plugin) should refer there.

Note that in the online version of the documentation only the plugins from the main gedit package are listed: https://help.gnome.org/users/gedit/stable/gedit-plugin-guide.html.en
The desktop help however also shows the plugins from gedit-plugins.
Might be a different bug in the online docs...

Technically the synctex plugin works, at least as far as i can tell with my setup.
Everything needed concerning TeX/LaTeX should be provided by TeX Live.

The documentation for the plugin would go to
`edit-plugins/help/C/synctex.page`? Is that right?

cheers

events.target_title: Synctex was completely removed from gedit

note.body:
Thanks for the hint on gnome-latex!

here's my merge request: !16

Crossreferences between documentation pages of different projects do not really work very well.
eg. the mouse over text shows the plain link reference.
and they do not work at all in "seealso" links.

Is there no other way than using `xref="help:evince/..."` ?

events.target_title: Add feature to run apps/games in native 4k without scaling.
Add feature to run apps/games in native 4k without scaling.

note.body:
Sorry I wrote that request here but not on gnome-shell, not sure where I should do it.
Also network in my home is so slow I can't respond nicely on this gitlab site. I'm now at work.

So, basically running in HiDPI resolution trying to avoid scaling should be available to every program, like on Windows 10. You get choice to set "System settings", which is rendering with scaling, or "App settings" which is native in your HiDPI resolution.

It's not possible with Gnome 3.28 from what I know.
Responding to question - every steam games that is capable of running in 4k, wine with games like Witcher 3, GTA V, FF XIV, and many others. It should be available to all, easy to switch. Maybe CLI parameter or PPM settings?

Thanks.

events.target_title: The battery icon is ALWAYS lying. 100% full icon for 50-100% battery. 85% full icon for 10-49%, a low battery icon for <10%.
The battery icon is ALWAYS lying. 100% full icon for 50-100% battery. 85% full icon for 10-49%, a low battery icon for <10%.

note.body:
3.28.2

Charge a functional laptop to full, observe battery icon through various states of discharge. I've been using GNOME for a few years, on different laptops, so this problem seemed universal.

events.target_title: The battery icon is ALWAYS lying. 100% full icon for 50-100% battery. 85% full icon for 10-49%, a low battery icon for <10%.

note.body:
link to "draw the charge level dynamically instead" is broken.

Definitely shouldn't show 85% full icon for 10-49%. Should stop showing full icon at, say 85% full, and start showing 85% full icon.

If the battery % was rounding with any reasonable rounding scheme to the nearest icon's battery %, then this wouldn't be "lying". But it's not rounding to the nearest icon. So it's "lying".

events.target_title: The battery icon is ALWAYS lying. 100% full icon for 50-100% battery. 85% full icon for 10-49%, a low battery icon for <10%.
The battery icon is ALWAYS lying. 100% full icon for 50-100% battery. 85% full icon for 10-49%, a low battery icon for <10%.

note.body:
https://linustechtips.com/main/topic/893479-fix-the-broken-battery-icon-in-gnome/

https://bugs.freedesktop.org/show_bug.cgi?id=93389

https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/upower/upower/issues/49

https://github.com/numixproject/numix-icon-theme/issues/966

This is seems to be universal, and while you might call it "expected behavior", because it was how GNOME was intentionally written, it's not expected. A reasonable user expects that the battery icon shown is the closest icon to the battery's actual %.

Just re-write the code for mapping actual % to icon, to instead of the current ranges, use ranges whose cutoffs are (more) equidistant from the %s shown in the default battery icons.

events.target_title: The battery icon is ALWAYS lying. 100% full icon for 50-100% battery. 85% full icon for 10-49%, a low battery icon for <10%.

note.body: @Andre, Can you just show me the mapping between actual % and icon? I don't think my individual experiences differ. I think the mapping is inaccurate, NOT that I have some bug where I'm not getting the same mapping scheme as everyone else. I don't know how to find anything inside GNOME's codebase.

events.target_title: The battery icon is ALWAYS lying. 100% full icon for 50-100% battery. 85% full icon for 10-49%, a low battery icon for <10%.

note.body:
@aklapper You can see the same problem in the 4 links I provided. Count them as mine. I don't want to discharge my battery just for this, but I'll probably do it in the next couple weeks, whenever I have to use the battery naturally.

I'm pretty certain you can just find the mapping of actual % to icon in the source code, and if you link me to the icons as well, I will open GIMP and figure out exactly what % each icon represents, and I will make the most accurate mapping and paste it here. It's a matter of GNOME's code being wrong for everyone, everywhere, all the time, not a bug on my various individual machines/linuxes/GNOMEs.

events.target_title: The battery icon is ALWAYS lying. 100% full icon for 50-100% battery. 85% full icon for 10-49%, a low battery icon for <10%.
The battery icon is ALWAYS lying. 100% full icon for 50-100% battery. 85% full icon for 10-49%, a low battery icon for <10%.

note.body:
@fmuellner upower to my knowledge is just finding the battery %, and doing so correctly.

In the code you linked, I see no mappings between actual % and icons. Can you please tell me which line numbers to focus on, to derive the map between %s to icons?

Or, more helpful, because I don't see the mapping in there anywhere, could you just write it down, and swear an oath that the mapping actually comes from the UPower code?

Example %s to icon mapping

Actual % : Icon %

60-100: 100%

11-59: 85%

0-10: 9%

This mapping scheme is the problem. It should be rounding to the nearest icon, but it's not. I don't think upower is doing that, but I'm no C expert. I am a beginner with some experience. My understanding is that upower reports the actual % to GNOME (and does so quite accurately). I still don't know 1. what is the icon mapping, 2. where is the icon mapping, and 2. more specifically, what code lines are responsible for it?

Also, please link to the icons themselves, so that I may measure their pixels, and find exactly what %s they represent.

Until you show me that the code mapping battery %s to icons and the icons are actually in UPower, and not in GNOME, I'm going to keep reopening the issue. Have patience with me, and don't close the issue before you have first made it clear that the icons themselves, and their mappings, both exist outside of GNOME. If either the icons, or the mapping relationship between actual % and icon exist inside GNOME, this is still GNOME's problem.

events.target_title: Improve Spacebar  pan-image operation

note.body:
I've faced this with zoom. Many a times, I have found myself entering "-" into the layer opacity, While my real intention was to just zoom out. 

I understand this program-wise. As the last operation I had done was to change the opacity, the opacity textbox had assumed focus. But user-experience wise: After a while, we don't really remember the state in our mind. What we need to ensure is Gimp is in a state that the user is assuming. 

The best solution I could think of, is to have a keyboard shortcut which resets the focus to the active image. Once the user is habituated, for any operation or keyboard - shortcut that needs the image to have focus, the user would precede it with the focusing shortcut.

multiple screens, broken icons and curious behaviour

note.body:
@mitch I wonder where your info about depreciation of multiple screen comes from, but regardless of that I  am not aware of any other possible method having two monitors with **vastly different DPI** used on the same environment, and I am very gladly listen to the state of art way of getting that done. 

Funny thing though, https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/multihead#Separate_screens spcifically writes *"With this configuration it is not possible to move windows between screens, apart from a few special programs like **GIMP** and Emacs which have multi-screen support."*

As for yourself: do you have multiple monitors, and at least one of them having at least double the resolution of the other? I have been tried various white and dark magic applied, but Linux DPI support seems to be hazy at best and absolutely nonworking for the less than best cases; varies from horribly-looking upscaled fonts and icons through broken layout to unreadable fonts or half-screen sized letters, depending on which is the default; and the settings may come (or being ignored) from various sources like a wide range of environment variables, xrdb, xserver settings and custom program controls.

But all of this isn't quite helping I guess. Multiple screens seem to be valid config, so it is supposed to work, I reckon. (I don't remember what the specific problem was with using multiple monitors on the same xserver but I guess it was also related to the DPI handling [update] Yes indeed, if the monitors are on the same display they share the same DPI settings [of some] which cannot be independently configured.)

As for the environment: it's debian sid, running xorg with the closed nvidia drivers, using xfce4 and it's xfwm4.

events.target_title: multiple screens, broken icons and curious behaviour

note.body: @Jehan Thanks, that's an understandable approach. You can decide whether to keep this bug (since it's a bug even if about a hardly ever used feature) or to close it as "nobody ever will do anything about it anyway". I have seen it and reported, but I am not aggressively pushing, I can live with it. :-)

events.target_title: gimp-help-2-2.8.2-de-setup.exe can't find installed GIMP 2.10.0

note.body:
Hi,

I had the same issue and the command line you should use is:

gimp-help-2-2.8.2-de-setup.exe" /VERYSILENT /DIR=%ProgramFiles%\GIMP 2\ /MSGBOX=YES /SUPPRESSMSGBOXES

You can also write a log. It´s showing :"Defaulting to Yes for suppressed message box (Yes/No):"

note.body:
Autocrypt itself tracks implementation status here:
https://autocrypt.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dev-status.html

pEp has an android app released on GooglePlay&F-Droid, has an Outlook Plugin and is also part of recent enigmail releases.
How many people that translates too is hard to tell as open source basically doesn't collect these numbers.

I wouldn't rate either of the two very high yet as you need to actively install a plugin  right now or switch to a non-default mail-client. Many people on mobile stick with the default app.

I would not call pEp a replacement to pgp, pEp is still compatible with all those people using pgp in a more traditional way.It is more like an agent handling the details for you.

I'm a developer, although I didn't build gimp from scratch (just testing otto's PPA on debian unstable). As long as you can give me specific tests to do I'd be willing to help.

Not using GNOME/KDE or anything else (no DE). No apparmor or selinux.

events.target_title: File export is creating useless (temporary?) files

note.body:
> @wavexx Are you saying this additional file appear all the time? It's
> not even a "*sometimes, sometimes not*" situation? If so, something is
> really fishy. I am pretty sure GIMP code does not create such file,
> even more as you say it happens for both PNG and JPEG.

It is always created.

I discovered by random experimentation that removing "Save Exif data"
doesn't create this file anymore.

> So this seriously raise even more possibility of some weird side
> external party messing with files, unless both libpng and libjpeg have
> the same temporary file logics (I doubt they even have any, it's not
> their role to manage such failures).

Looks plausible to me that this could be an issue in exiv2.
It looks like there were several security reports about temporary file
creation which could affect this.

> Note that this is not an official release.

I know, I know.. but otto's PPA is a nightly automated rebuild from git.
flatpak is fun and everything, but I'd like to find the root cause of
this irregardless of the source. If your build works, but debian
doesn't, you're happy but I still want to report to someone ;)

I'll have a loot at what I can check in exiv2 now..

GtkTrayIcon has no background on X11

note.body:
The problem with the first patch is that the GDK code will sometimes remove the background, and then set it back to None, breaking the effects of the initial call to `XSetWindowBackgroundPixmap`. I've seen this happen on several occasions, though I'm not sure exactly how to reproduce it. I've tried both with and without the `gdk_window_set_background_pattern (window, NULL);` call, but it doesn't seem to make a difference.

The second patch is also written in such a way that it's as easy as possible to maintain as a distro patch, so I had to sacrifice elegance a little. It can definitely be cleaned up.

events.target_title: GtkTrayIcon has no background on X11

note.body:
As far as I know, xembed windows (which tray icons are) are never touched by compositors because they are not direct children of the root window. Maybe Mutter actually cheats and handles them, but no other window manager does.

I can reproduce this problem on i3 with and without a compositor running.

note.body:
Gimp continues to freeze and/or crash when using the **Lastend theme.**

**Lastend** theme is a third party theme and does not come with the installer.

When I use** Lastend** theme, Gimp immediately gets "bogged down" and is unresponsive at best; crashes at worst.

I have increased the cache and threshold settings and that does not help.

I can't switch to Gimp ver. 2.10.6 because it is not available for MAC.

I am going to have my hard drive analyzed to see if that might be part of the problem.

I have 32 gigabytes of ram and ram is never the issue.

Reduce confusion from magenta out-of-gamut color indicators

note.body:
GPick already uses "stripes" for this purpose, and I got some feedback from Twitter when I posted a CIECAM slider interface I'm working on.  Using a particular solid color is problematic when you are picking colors similar to that.  So, anything non-color really; stripes, checkerboard, dots, would probably work better.

Also, it might be handy to automatically "gamut map" the color someone picked from a "stripe zone" so that it is a valid non-negative color for their working color space.  I suppose a checkbox to enable/disable that would afford the most flexibility.

LUT monitor profile issues with GIMP-2.99 and GIMP-2.10

note.body:
The current GIMP behavior doesn't correspond with how users expect it to work, or how other ICC Color Management Modules (such as lcms or ArgyllCMS etc.) work.

If a user has gone to the trouble to create and provide a more detailed, cLUT based ICC profile rather than an Matrix based profile, then they expect the cLUT to be used rather than any Matrix present.

So the babl logic for doing the color conversion itself should really be:

```
if source profile has an A2B tag
or if source profile doesn't have a matrix tag
of if destination profile has a B2A tag
or if destination profile doesn't have a matrix tag
then use lcms to do the color transform.
```

i.e. the default GIMP CMM tag priority should be cLUT > Matrix > Monochrome.

A comprehensive set of CMM controls might provide a user option to reverse this priority, i.e. see <http://www.argyllcms.com/doc/xicclu.html#o> for an example.

events.target_title: LUT monitor profile issues with GIMP-2.99 and GIMP-2.10

note.body:
>  Is there any other identifying information about these profiles indicating that the matrix of the profile is deliberately incorrect and should not be used - a hard-coded constant set that isn't also used for other debugging?

No - the CMM doesn't need to know whether the matrix information is correct or not, it just needs to have a consistent priority of tag use. You are using an amalgam of lcms and babl, so the right thing to do is to make your amalgam self consistent, which means making it have the same priority behavior as lcms and other CMMs. I've given the logic in my previous post that will solve the problem and result in consistent behavior - you haven't explained why this isn't easy to implement, or why it is at all problematic.

events.target_title: LUT monitor profile issues with GIMP-2.99 and GIMP-2.10

note.body:
>  The interactive performance of GIMP for painting and more _really_ benefits from being able to use SIMD accelerated matrix+TRC path instead of going through lcms2 for either matrix or cLUT based conversions, which is part of why a good monitor profile should contain valid matrix+trc data. Longer term the goal for babl is to also deal with cLUTs itself, but also then profiles with consistent data will be preferable.

Matrix and cLUT are not interchangeable from a color quality point of view - a matrix has much less information/detail on the behavior of a device.
So when you come across an ICC profile with both cLUT and Matrix tags, this doesn't mean to the CMM that it can use either. The Matrix tags are there as a fall back, for the (hopefully few) CMMs still out there that don't handle cLUT conversions. 

What that means is that if GIMP is given a profile pair that contain only matrix information, the the user us telling you "a matrix is accurate enough for me". On the other hand, if one of the profiles contain cLUT data, the user is telling you "I really care about color quality, and have gone to the trouble of creating and providing a higher detail cLUT profile. I am prioritizing color quality over speed".

I think it is best to honor their wishes, rather than make a speed/quality choice for them that is the opposite of what they want.

If they decide that they want speed over color quality, then they can easily choose to use a matrix only profile (every ICC display profiling package can generate a matrix only profile.) 

And this is the right thing do do from an application consistency point of view, since other CMMs prioritize cLUT over matrix, for exactly the reasons I give above.

events.target_title: LUT monitor profile issues with GIMP-2.99 and GIMP-2.10

note.body:
> And such fallback for lack of capability or in future need of performance during dynamic shift to performance over accuracy interactive operations and preview, is what I expected - but not what the tags are used for in these profiles. For now I am assuming that any profiles with TRC+matrix+clut ant unlikely red chromaticity is such a profile.

It's simply wrong for you to assume that performance is the priority, when the user has clearly indicated that quality is the priority by providing a cLUT profile. It's clearly wrong for GIMP to have a CMM that uses a different tag priority to every other application and CMM out there.

Since you don't seem to understand that you are working against the users
in all this, I guess my only option now is to change Argyll's XYZ cLUT default to remove the matrix tags, so that they are able to force their
preference of quality over speed when using GIMP.

events.target_title: LUT monitor profile issues with GIMP-2.99 and GIMP-2.10

note.body:
>in a future and more complete state, GIMP would make use of the shaper part of the profile in a consistent clut+matrix profile 

Umm. That's really bad - the profile simply isn't being used in a valid way if you are just using the matrix tag and not implementing the full ICC gamma/shaper + matrix color transform.

events.target_title: LUT monitor profile issues with GIMP-2.99 and GIMP-2.10

note.body: @ok And I also am trying to improve things, but this is difficult when you don't seem to want to engage in any substantive discussion of the issue.

events.target_title: Add plugin for the Clang Language Server
Add plugin for the Clang Language Server
Add plugin for the Clang Language Server

note.body:
OTOH, `clangd` is adding features as a faster rate than the existing Builder plugin (I think it already provides more features). The industry is quickly moving towards a model where languages provide their own Language Server implementation and IDEs just pick it up from there. This is the right model because the language authors have both the domain knowledge and the economic incentive to provide high quality tooling.

Intentionally moving toward this model in Builder means that there is less code in Builder and faster innovation. Further, it allows Builder to focus on delivering a high quality Language Server implementation rather than maintaining its own languages.

In short:
  * Less Code
  * Less Bugs
  * More Features

To me, faster and more memory efficient are non-features when `clangd` is GoodEnoughTM in this regard and, at the same time, has more development features and a faster development rate.

events.target_title: Add plugin for the Clang Language Server

note.body:
> The JSON parsing in language servers creates a great deal of
> memory fragmentation and I don't want that in the UI process.

Is memory fragmentation actually a measured issue? If so, then Builder already has this issue with rust-langserv and go-langserv. What is the measurable impact over, say, an 8-12 hour workday? As someone who has spent a 12 hour day coding in Rust in Builder, I can certainly say that I never noticed any problems.

Assuming it does have a measurable impact, it would be possible to use your GVariant system to an external LSP process which proxies all requests to the actual LSP. This would isolate the fragmentation to one process which could be respawned.

>  We also have a lot of extensions that would be lossy if we
> started using LSP as the intermediate protocol.

Can you help me understand this? I'm just not sure what this means.

> But we would lose even more features too. For example, our
> code-search index does all of the indexing in the sub-process and
> then sends back the index data to be merged into the search indexes.

This doesn't strike me as a feature. It strikes me as an internal optimization. Is it measurably necessary? If I had to trade this for rename support, I'd pick rename support any day of the week.

> IIRC, clangd requires `compile_commands.json` to determine any sort of
> compilation information. That would reduce the number of build systems
> we support and also break our ability to work across mount namespaces.
> While this is rather expensive on some build systems, it is something
> we could work around.

This information is already necessary for the existing C/C++ plugin on all build systems. It just needs to be modified to output in `compile_commands.json` into the build directory. Builder should be able to generate this and provide the path to `clangd`. I don't understand how, if it is impossible for `clangd` it isn't already impossible for the existing plugin. I'm happy to be informed.

========================================================

What I'd love to see Builder move to is a model where there is a new type of plugin which is handed all the build information for a project after the first build and the job of the plugin is to take this information and produce a working LSP instance (possibly multiple per project). Builder could also then re-spawn the LSPs if it detects build instruction changes. This would enable contributors to efficiently add LSP-based plugins.

events.target_title: Application focus is not returned to app after dismissing a Notification

note.body:
After some experiments, I have a theory about this weird behavior, but I don't know what caused it, neither do I know how to fix it... 

`xprop` shows the following windows during an interaction with some notifications:
```
$ xprop -spy -root _NET_ACTIVE_WINDOW
_NET_ACTIVE_WINDOW(WINDOW): window id # 0x4200007  ## original window
_NET_ACTIVE_WINDOW(WINDOW): window id # 0x0        ## mouse over notification popup
_NET_ACTIVE_WINDOW(WINDOW): window id # 0x0        ## ... triggers TWO window changes
_NET_ACTIVE_WINDOW(WINDOW): window id # 0x4200007  ## need to click to re-focus
```
Note that `window id # 0x0` is triggered *TWICE* when hovering over the notification popup. Therefore the original window focus might fail to be recorded in the `FocusGrabber.grabFocus()` method in `js/ui/messageTray.js`, and subsequently fail to be restored in the `ungrabFocus()` method. 

See:
https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/blob/master/js/ui/messageTray.js#L83

Please check!

events.target_title: Night Light should support "Always on" schedule

note.body:
@aklapper screen calibration and "night light" have different purposes.

Screen calibration is a thing you do once and it never changes. Night Light can be switched on and off every time you want.

I know a lot of people who use Night Light as I use it. Most of them are programmers who use the PC all the day.

Imagine you use your PC 10 hours a day, and for 9 hours you only have to write stuff. Then you need your screen perfectly calibrated for designing stuff or something similar. With "Night mode" you have only to click to the top-right of the screen to turn it off.

I think you are underestimating the number of people who use Night Light in this way, combined with dark themes.
I also think there won't be drawbacks on implementing this feature.

events.target_title: Night Light should support "Always on" schedule

note.body:
@kowalski.7cc is right, this is a screenshot on how Windows 10 manages this feature.
![photo6046538973620317202](/uploads/ca9823e69a2ffc401cb49b0c6564287a/photo6046538973620317202.jpg)

events.target_title: Night Light should support "Always on" schedule

note.body:
@feaneron no it's not.

Night mode was born (not only on Gnome) to work as a replacement for a blue filter.
The name "night" came up because it was historically implemented to improve sleep quality to people who suffer from sleep disorders.
It has nothing to do with "twilight and dawn" (even if turning on night mode in that range of time could improve your sleep).
People who have sleep disorders usually enable it "always on" and disable it only if it has to do something related to graphics.
It has also other advantages, but it's not the place to discuss that.

Colour profile is a completely different thing which has different goals (e.g. helping provide consistency between devices).

Last but not least, in the future software like VLC and GIMP could disable "night light" when you're watching a video or you're editing a photo and re-enabling it if enabled before.

Other OSs allow you to set Night Mode always on and f.lux allows that (correct me if I'm wrong). As I said before, there are no drawbacks to implementing it.

events.target_title: Night Light should support "Always on" schedule

note.body:
@feaneron I am wrong or it's just a button?

If it's a problem, I'll make a PR myself. I don't think there will be enormous problems linked to maintenance. Please correct me if I'm wrong.

IMHO it's a nice-to-have feature and we don't have to hide behind the "maintenance it's a pain in the ass". There are gnome features which are less useful but still there.
There are also DEs which manage the "Night Mode" in the right way, I simply don't understand why we have to keep this (wrong) way of doing it.

events.target_title: Night Light should support "Always on" schedule

note.body:
>  At last, this is the first and last warning about passive-aggressive comments.

It's not a passive-aggressive comment, it's just that I'm not a native speaker. I'm sorry if you feel that I'm attacking you in some way, because I don't.

> You're saying now that Night Light is neither about night, nor light. Either you have a deep misunderstanding of it, or I do.

Again, that's because I'm not fluent. I'm sorry. I said it's not related to a precise range of the day (like you said: ""Night light" is the name of the specific behaviour of changing the colour temperature between twilight and dawn").

>  Indeed, I meant to say "color calibration".

Again, colour calibration has different purposes.


>  Night Light was introduced in GNOME with the specific purpose of reducing eye strain during the night by matching the natural light temperature.

I don't know why it was introduced in GNOME, but it has not only the purpose of reducing eye strain during the night. Publications in the field also showed us eye diseased linked to short-wavelength light and it strongly related, as I said before, with sleep disorders.

Lots of people I know are using this feature in the way I'm using it, so there would be two options:
*  you're right and they are wrong; DEs and tools out there are wrong too;
* people started using it for purposes different from what GNOME developers have imagined;

> It's not nice to have broken experiences. And it _is_ a PITA to maintain. Of course, you don't know that - you don't maintain it. 

Let's imagine you're right and it's hard to maintain. What's the purpose of GNOME? It's better having tools which are easy to maintain but it doesn't have features that other DEs have or the opposite? I don't have the answer, just pointing out a nice-to-have potential new feature.

At this point, I'm feeling constantly repeating things. If you think this feature doesn't need to be on GNOME it's ok, but the discussion reached a deadlock.

```
# thumb button closes windows
"xdo close `xdotool getmouselocation --shell 2>/dev/null | grep WINDOW | sed "s/.*=\(.*\)/\1/"`"

events.target_title: Ability to change Date format

note.body:
I'm simple GNOME user but I would like to express my opinion.

I personally see no clear benefits of displaying date in ISO 8601 format. But If somebody need this feature, it's possible to add such info in Nautilius without recompilling. Not by configuration in GUI but by simple plugin.

See:

![Zrzut_ekranu_z_2019-09-27_17-52-16](/uploads/429cc48866e078d7fc01738d00f093b2/Zrzut_ekranu_z_2019-09-27_17-52-16.png)

I've played a little with nautilus-python module, and found writing custom column providers extremely easy. In my opinion good extension architecture superseedes a lot of unnecessary configuration options in GUI, but if somebody provide valid use case for other time&date formats I will be happy to see that in Nautilus config.

Code (translation support omitted for simplicity, edit strings if needed ;)):

``` python
import time

import gi
gi.require_version('Gio', '2.0')
gi.require_version('GLib', '2.0')
gi.require_version('GObject', '2.0')
from gi.repository import Nautilus, GObject, Gio

class ColumnExtension(GObject.GObject, Nautilus.ColumnProvider, Nautilus.InfoProvider):
    def __init__(self):
        pass
    
    def get_columns(self):
        return (
            Nautilus.Column(name="NautilusPython::access_time_column",
                            attribute="access_time",
                            label="Access time",
                            description="Access time in ISO8601 format"),
            Nautilus.Column(name="NautilusPython::modification_time_column",
                            attribute="modification_time", label="Last modification",
                            description="Last modification time in ISO8601 format")
        )

    def update_file_info(self, file):
        if file.get_uri_scheme() != 'file':
            return
        
        file_info = file.get_location().query_info("time::*", flags=Gio.FileQueryInfoFlags(0), cancellable=None)
        format = "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M"
        
        file.add_string_attribute('access_time', time.strftime(format, time.localtime(file_info.get_attribute_uint64("time::access"))))
        file.add_string_attribute('modification_time', time.strftime(format, time.localtime(file_info.get_attribute_uint64("time::modified"))))
```

Just make sure that yours OS has nautilus-python installed and put this code in `~/.local/share/nautilus-python/extensions/nautilus-ISO8601.py` and enjoy! ;)

events.target_title: Ability to change Date format

note.body:
Well, I'm not omniscient so I can be wrong and you can be right but I see this whole issue like this:

There are lot of people using nautilus. Every single one can have their own preferred date&time format so Nautilus will gain nothing by adding 2 different or 10 different formats in preferences until you add all possible formats, or there is possibility to define your own string for formatting date. And going further this way – why not add way for user to add more columns with info? Why not make it possible to show length of video or size of photo? Why not make it possible to show random number in it's own column? To make this totally universal you need some scripting support – and here we have current plugin architecture.

But some of yours point are valid — adding scripting support can be security risk, but on the other hand — I've seen longer and more complicated configuration files than provided python script. I think that even non-programmer can simply understand what provided code will do and how change it.

events.target_title: g_clear_pointer may not use the correct calling convention with its callback

note.body:
Actually the `typeof()` is used to solve `pp` cast, not `destroy` cast, you can use `destroy` directly to avoid that macro problem.

See also https://lists.freedesktop.org/archives/spice-devel/2018-August/045353.html.

The combinations of all versions and macro/not macro are quite confusing and potentially easily causing different bugs just changing compiler or glib version. Documentation seems mostly related to the function which is actually never used as the macro is replacing it.

events.target_title: g_clear_pointer may not use the correct calling convention with its callback

note.body:
I would go with something like

```diff
diff --git a/glib/gmem.h b/glib/gmem.h
index 81f8cdde3..b2a384458 100644
--- a/glib/gmem.h
+++ b/glib/gmem.h
@@ -114,6 +114,7 @@ gpointer g_try_realloc_n  (gpointer  mem,
 #define g_clear_pointer(pp, destroy)                                           \
   G_STMT_START {                                                               \
     G_STATIC_ASSERT (sizeof *(pp) == sizeof (gpointer));                       \
+    /* Only one access, please */                                              \
     __typeof__((pp)) _pp = (pp);                                               \
     __typeof__(*(pp)) _ptr = *_pp;                                             \
     *_pp = NULL;                                                               \
@@ -127,15 +128,13 @@ gpointer g_try_realloc_n  (gpointer        mem,
     /* Only one access, please; work around type aliasing */                   \
     union { char *in; gpointer *out; } _pp;                                    \
     gpointer _p;                                                               \
-    /* This assignment is needed to avoid a gcc warning */                     \
-    GDestroyNotify _destroy = (GDestroyNotify) (destroy);                      \
                                                                                \
     _pp.in = (char *) (pp);                                                    \
     _p = *_pp.out;                                                             \
     if (_p)                                                                   \
       {                                                                       \
         *_pp.out = NULL;                                                       \
-        _destroy (_p);                                                         \
+        (destroy) (_p);                                                        \
       }                                                                        \
   } G_STMT_END

The hung task window tries to appear and the syslog is spammed. The workaround about keeping the activity view open while the game starts does allow the game to start. At least there is a workaround, but this is a pretty serious issue.

events.target_title: "“<application>” is not responding" dialog caused shell to become unresponsive

note.body: An easier, no-patch workaround, is to start the game and immediately open the activities window (Windows key or top left hot corner). This stops the force close / wait dialog from hanging up gnome shell. Rocket League is also a game affected by this regression. Shell / Mutter 3.32 didn't hang.

First of all thank you for your quick answer :)

I tried what you suggested and I confirm that they works perfectly as you described, my problem (which I forgot to mention in my previous post) was that I launched baobab on a remote system forwarding X11 via ssh (usually with Cygwin/X server on Windows workstations).
I never tried to mount remote filesystems over Nautilus, in that way the baobab 2.28.1 gave me the option to only the "Custom Location" option and not "Scan the remote folder" (http://www.imagebam.com/image/2a01e3954037504), running on a proper Gnome instance it's ok.

events.target_title: New search behavior using type-ahead search by default

note.body:
A really useful feature that would at least improve the way current search works would be to allow different search strategies for 'just typing' and 'pressing Ctrl+F'. For example limiting the search to only the current folder when 'just typing' and searching subfolders when 'pressing Ctrl+F'. Ideally this could be toggled in the dropdown where you already can select if you want to search in fulltext or the filename only.
Any opinions on that?

events.target_title: Full file list deterioates usability
Full file list deterioates usability

note.body:
Oh, I apologize for posting an issue that is already adressed.

But for **1. Selection overlay hides file info** I have to add an additional comment, not sure where to post it though, as the other issues seem to involve greater design changes and my solution does not.

So: This issue is clearly not a big problem and does not immediately justify greater design changes (at least not for this issue).
Therefore I wonder if a quick patch would suffice.
The selection info overlay covers only about 70% of the last item's height. I think it would be a very easy and not too ugly solution if a margin/padding/etc was added to the list. One could then scroll ~ 1 item-height further than currently possible and the overlay would not interfere with the last file.
I suppose this would also be not too difficult to implement?

events.target_title: GIMP 2.10 crashed with an incorrect third-party theme
Fonts that are part of the same typefaces are ignored
Fonts that are part of the same typefaces are ignored

note.body:
Somebody suggested this may be similar to #1228 but I don't see the comment now. Yes, definitely it could, except the scale of it seems bigger with me - anything but the regular font isn't appearing as a separate design.

I do have a bit more info. I contacted the font seller who kindly sent me two font files (.otf) he'd named differently (using a font editor I presume, not just by renaming the .otf files in a file manager). So instead of being named Southfield-Alt2.otf, the new file is named SouthfieldAlt2-Alt2.otf. These worked! GIMP read them correctly. So it appears to be related to the fact that GIMP is reading the font family main name before the dash and if it's identical, ignoring what comes after, or something like that. Unfortunately I do not know how to generate fonts that correct for this problem. Does anyone know the steps  to do this for a font code ignoramus using FontForge? Might it be possible for developers to fix this bug? Thank you so much!

events.target_title: Fonts that are part of the same typefaces are ignored

note.body: OK, this is interesting. I just installed Krita and tried to look at the fonts with the text module. It appears a very similar thing is happening there, except instead of listing multiple "duplicate" fonts, it just lists the first. So like, it just lists one Cooper-Hewitt instead of a bunch of them. The "fixed" file names that I mentioned in the above comment display correctly. So it may be that the bug is in some package that both these open source programs are using?

events.target_title: Fonts that are part of the same typefaces are ignored

note.body: Hi, any hope that anyone's interested in tracking down a fix for this? Or are we pretty much out of luck with the fancy font packages?

events.target_title: Fonts that are part of the same typefaces are ignored

note.body:
Thank you, Jehan. To be honest, I'm grateful for anything being done at any time with open source.

It happens in all of the fonts here: https://creativemarket.com/WornOutMedia/1954506-Typographers-Dream-Box-200-Logos
And here:
https://creativemarket.com/creatype/2643973-Striped-King-Vintage-Script
And here
https://www.fontsquirrel.com/fonts/cooper-hewitt
Also many more, of course, but at this point we stopped compiling lists.

Lillolollo, thank you. I read that to the extent that I can understand it. But I admit to a confusion as to why it should be relegated to a font problem when 1)it works in LibreOffice, and 2) When the font maker renamed it using his font software as I described above, it solved the problem. Shouldn't software be reading fonts with simple naming anomalies? I kind of thought my penultimate two comments starting "Somebody" and "OK" might provide clues as to where the problem is. Maybe. Hopefully. 

I guess to resolve the logic of whether it's a font or software problem, I imagine a story like this: 

A beautiful princess named Gimpla went to a ball and met many handsome suitors. One of them, Prince Fontface, had prickly spines instead of hair on his head. Since that was slightly disturbing, she ignored him all night. When it came time to pick her Prince, Prince Fontface cried out, "You refuse to dance with me. Why won't you even look at me?" And she said, "It's your fault for being ugly. If you would bother to cover up your hair, maybe I would." And he said, "Really? I've danced with many princesses tonight. I'm thinking it's YOUR fault for not recognizing who I am beneath the ugliness. Try looking at me - the REAL me." And when she finally sighed, rolled her eyes, circled him a few times, and squinted at him from the shadows, she gasped, for now that she looked closely, she saw the truth. And she reached up, whipped off his helmet of spines, and revealed soft hair with gorgeous, fancy swirls...and clearly he was her soulmate. They lived fontly ever after.

events.target_title: In-window AppMenu doesn't appear on GNOME 3.29 Wayland
the icon in the corner of the windows do not scale

note.body:
I can reproduce this on GNOME 3.28.3 on Xorg with GNOME Terminal 3.28.2 and Papirus icon theme. I wasn't able to reproduce this on any other apps except gnome-terminal. It is a problem with the default Adwaita icon theme as well because the icon looks blurry on my HiDPI display. The icon is blurry on Gnome 3.28 Xorg session with all icon themes I tried including Adwaita, Moka, Yaru, etc. With Papirus it's blurry and too big. This doesn't happen on Gnome 3.28 Wayland, the icon is sharp and correct size with all themes.

This is not reproducible on GNOME 3.29.91 due to the icon not appearing at all on both Wayland and Xorg. On Wayland none of the AppMenu icons appear at all which I just reported in Mutter issue [#276](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/issues/276). And on Xorg just the icon for gnome terminal doesn't appear.

events.target_title: Flatpak: No folders or conversations displayed, no new mail downloaded

note.body:
You were right, I had not waited enough. The .deb version freezes all the time while it is refreshing the inbox, so since I could click on the little arrow next to the account, I thought it had finished attempting to sync.

The `Download mail: 2 weeks back` setting in Accounts is not respected though, it's downloading all my inbox. I'm not sure if this is a separate regression, or if that behaviour was introduced because Geary is forced to sync even if there is supposedly no network.

Can't disable Night Light

note.body:
Agreed.  Since it's nighttime where I am, my Night Light setting is on and active.

```
$ gsettings list-recursively org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.color
org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.color night-light-schedule-automatic true
org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.color priority 0
org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.color recalibrate-display-threshold uint32 0
org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.color night-light-last-coordinates (38.188000000000002, -85.836500000000001)
org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.color night-light-enabled true
org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.color night-light-schedule-from 20.0
org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.color night-light-schedule-to 6.0
org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.color night-light-temperature uint32 4980
org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.color recalibrate-printer-threshold uint32 0
org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.color active true
$ gsettings get org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.color night-light-enabled
true
```

I turned it off and the display immediately cycled through several temperature settings (one of which was daytime temp.) and finally settled back to the nighttime temp.

```
$ gsettings list-recursively org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.color
org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.color night-light-schedule-automatic true
org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.color priority 0
org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.color recalibrate-display-threshold uint32 0
org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.color night-light-last-coordinates (38.188000000000002, -85.836500000000001)
org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.color night-light-enabled false
org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.color night-light-schedule-from 20.0
org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.color night-light-schedule-to 6.0
org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.color night-light-temperature uint32 4980
org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.color recalibrate-printer-threshold uint32 0
org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.color active true
$ gsettings get org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.color night-light-enabled
false
```

I tried to do a screen record of the action but it didn't show the color cycling.  However, I was able to capture a video on my phone that showed what I'm experiencing[0].

[0] https://photos.app.goo.gl/3B5tYoNjzCZd6peC9

At one point I did play with Redshift but I'm not sure it was on this OS install.  I looked for any stray Redshift packages or installs and couldn't find anything.  Also, nothing with the name 'redshift' is in my process list.  Hmmmm...

I am running a Ryzen 5 2400 with the built-in Radeon Vega graphics (no video card).  I had to go through quite a bit of trouble (upgrading kernels, BIOS firmware updates, etc.) to get the system to work and be stable, but that shouldn't cause this issue, I wouldn't think.

I found the problem - f.lux was running in the background!  Once I found and killed it NightLight started working perfectly.

@bberg I'm so sorry for all the confusion and trouble I've caused.  I just want to say that you have been very responsive with this whole thing and I really appreciate it.  In fact, it was your hint about Redshift that tipped me off.  I updated my kernel and when I rebooted I noticed that f.lux GUI was running.  Bingo!
